display.text: • Give frequent small sips from a cup.
• If the child vomits, wait 10 minutes. Then continue but more slowly.
• Continue with other fluids the child will accept.
• If eyes become puffy, too much fluid is being given so stop ORS and continue with breast milk or water.
• Reassess the child and classify the child for dehydration.
• Select the appropriate plan to continue treatment.
DOES THE MOTHER NEED TO LEAVE BEFORE COMPLETING TREATMENT?

display.text: SHOW THECAREGIVER HOW MUCH FLUID TO GIVE IN ADDITION TO THE USUAL FLUID INTAKE:
1/4 cup to 1/2 cup (50-100 ml) after EACH loose stool
display.hint: Age 2 months up to 2 years

display.text: 1/2 cup to 1 cup (100-200 ml) after EACH loose stool
display.hint: Age 2 years and older

1. Give frequent small sips from a cup.
  2. If the child vomits, wait 10 minutes. Then continue but more slowly.
  3. Continue giving extra fluid until the diarrhoea stops.

DiarrhoeaTX.comments: In accordance with the note, blood in stool and fever only appear if the child doesn't already have them

display.hint:
1. Child gets worse
  2. Passes more watery stools
  3. Vomits repeatedly
  4. Not able to drink or breastfeed
  5. Becomes very thirsty
  6. Develops fever or blood in stools if child doesn't already have them
  7. Child is not better in 2 days

Instruct caregiver to continue to dry the ear at least 4 times DAILY

display.hint: <li>Roll clean absorbent cloth or soft, strong tissue paper into a wick
<li>Place the wick in the young infant's ear
<li>Remove the wick after one minute or when wet
<li>Replace the wick with a clean one and repeat these steps until the ear is dry
<li>Nothing should be left in the ear between wicking
<li>If bleeding occurs, drying the ear should be stopped temporarily
<li>Child should avoid swimming or getting the inside of the ear wet

  4. Avoid spicy, salty, or acidic foods

Give adequate servings of family foods at 3 meals each day.
Also, twice dail, give nutritious food between meals
A good quality diet should include energy-rich foods (thick cereal, meat, fish, eggs, fruits, and vegetables)

display.hint:
• Continue feeding if the child is sick
  • Clear a blocked nose if it intereferes with feeding
  • Expect that the appetite will improve as child gets better

display.text:
• Keep the child in your lap and feed with your own hands
  • Wash your child's hands with soap and water every time before feeding
If the child has a poor appetite:
display.hint:
• Plan small, frequent meals
  • Give milk rather than other fluids except where there is diarrhoea with some dehydration
  • Give snacks between meals
  • Give high energy foods
  • Check frequently

display.text: If the child has sore mouth or ulcers:

display.hint:
• Give soft foods that will not burn the mouth, such as eggs, mashed potatoes, pumpkin, or avocado
  • Avoid spicy, salty, or acidic foods
  • Chop foods finely
  • Give cold drinks or ice, if available
